bestBHT.bht: John Mark, previously censured by Paul, is now praised for his usefulness in the Gospel ministry. The change in Paul's opinion of Mark is evident as he desires to have him as a companion and values his assistance. The connection between Mark and Luke is worth noting, with Luke being the author of the Gospel and Acts. Paul longs to have Mark, whom he had once rejected, as he finds him profitable for his ministry.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: John Mark was probably in, or near, Colosse, as in the Epistle to the Colossians (Colossians 4:10), written two years before this, he is mentioned as about to visit them.

Paul, appropriately here, wipes out the past censure by high praise of Mark and guards against Timothy's making self-complacent comparisons between himself and Mark, as though he were superior to the latter.
Mark returns to the right way, and is no longer unprofitable, but is profitable for the Gospel ministry.
Albert Barnes: For he is profitable to me for the ministry.
Marvin Vincent: Luke. His connection with Paul appears first in Acts 16:10. He remained at Philippi after Paul 's departure, and was there seven years later, when Paul revisited the city (Acts 20:5, Acts 20:6).
Mark. Mentioned Colossians 4:10; Philippians 1:24; 1 Peter 5:13. Probably John Mark (Acts 12:12, Acts 12:25; Acts 14:37), called the cousin of Barnabas (Col 6:10).
Profitable for the ministry [ευχρηστος εις διακονιαν] . Eucrhstov profitable, only here, chapter 2 Timothy 2:21, Philippians 1:11.
Philip Schaff: Mark, it would seem, had been left with Timothy at Ephesus.
It is pleasant to note in this last mention of him the fullest recantation of the adverse opinion recorded in Acts 15:38. He is now ‘profitable’ (better, ‘ useful ’) for the ministry.
Archibald T. Robertson: Take Mark. He is useful to me.
Paul had long ago changed his opinion of Mark because Mark had changed his conduct and had made good in his ministry.
Now Paul longs to have the man that he once scornfully rejected.
John Gill: Only Luke is with me... who wrote the Gospel that bears his name, and 'the Acts of the Apostles', and was a constant companion of Paul's in his travels and sufferings.
Take Mark, and bring him with thee... the apostle had entertained a better opinion of him, and was reconciled unto him, and was very desirous of his company and assistance.
For he is profitable to me for the ministry; that is, of the Gospel, to assist in preaching it.
John Wesley: But God is with me; and it is enough.
Take Mark — Who, though he once 'departed from the work,' is now again profitable to me.
